newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russians confirm mystery leak but say wasn't fuel.
newsitem.headline: Russians confirm mystery leak but say wasn't fuel.

text.p: A senior official at Mission Control confirmed on Saturday there had been a mystery leak from the holed Spektr science module on Russia's Mir space station five days ago but said experts were sure it was not of fuel.

"Only one thing is clear -- it was not fuel," a senior communications specialist told Reuters on condition he not be identified. "But apart from that no one has an answer yet to this mystery." A NASA official said earlier there had been an as yet unexplained incident and that experts were concerned.
"Five days ago, in one of our communications with the crew, we were told they had seen flakes and bubbles from an unknown source leaking from the Spektr module," the specialist said.

He said experts were trying to analyse information from the three-man crew -- two Russian cosmonauts and a British-born NASA astronaut. The crew ran into trouble on June 25 when a cargo craft hit the station during a manual docking test and punctured the Spektr science module.
"We do not have any information on the situation inside the Spektr module," the specialist said. "Measurements show there have been no other leaks in the other modules and sections of the station."
He said the three men were feeling fine and had spent the day making checks ready for the arrival of a new Progress cargo tug with repair supplies. Sunday would be a rest day.
